data.title: search in files focus resets when line changed
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:44:55.542Z)
- OS Version: Linux x64 4.4.0-62-generic
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|glslx-vscode|evanw|0.0.8|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.10.1|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.7.0|
|mono-debug|ms-vscode|0.13.0|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.3|
|arduino-vscode|steveyin|0.2.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. ctrl-shift-f search for a string that appears at least 3 times
2. hit F4 a TWO times to go to the 2nd result.
  - notice how in the search window the focused result is hilighted
3. now, edit the file (that contains the 2nd search result) so the line in that file no longer matches the search criteria.
 - notice how the 2nd search result disappears from the search results pane, and NO results are hilighted.
4. hit F4 again.
  - BUG: the first search result is hilighted.

expected: F4 should progress to the new 2nd search result (which was previously the 3rd result).

this bug breaks the process of using F4 to skip through results selectively editing, since every time you make an edit you have to start back at the beginning of the result. for hundreds of results, and many to skip repeatedly, this is extremely annoying.

data.title: Allow to pin an editor when saving explicitly
data.body:
When a new tab is opened via fuzzy-finder, it's italic and will be replaced by another fuzzy-found tab unless changes are made to the file.

Is there a natural key command other than `space` > `backspace` for keeping a tab around (making it "sticky") when it was opened by fuzzy-finder?

And if not, how about `cmd`+`s` (saving) stickies a tab? (someone help me out with language, here) I believe Atom supports this behavior.

data.title: Dynamic Editor Font Zoom
data.body:
I would like to submit a feature request to hold down the Ctrl key and use the mouse wheel to zoom text size in and out. Basically this would bind Ctrl + Mouse Wheel to dynamically set "editor.fontsize". Please refer to Sublime Text, Atom, or NotePad++ for functional demonstration.

This text-zoom feature should NOT change the size of Visual Studio Code's menu, left side menu, or other UI elements that currently do scale when performing Ctrl + , and Ctrl -
It should only scale the font size in the editor window.

data.title: Add menu item that would launch a build task
data.body: Please add menu item to #vscode that launches build task (ctrl+shift+b). In my projects I am editing and transpiling TypeScript, but this feature would apply more generally.

data.title: VirtualEnv Environment Variables no longer honored when starting with 'code .' from terminal
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.9.1
- OS Version: OSX 10.12.3

Description of Issue:
Matplotlib does not inherently work with VSCode debugger and Virtual Env. A runtime error occurs that states Python is not installed as a framework. A solution to this problem is provided [here](http://matplotlib.org/2.0.0b4/faq/osx_framework.html). The solution relies on the `code .` operator loading the environment variables from that virtual env. Up until 1.9.1 this worked just fine. 

I rolled back to 1.8 to make sure I wasn't crazy and indeed it still works. In 1.8 I was able to load my folder into vs code from terminal using `code .` and modify my launch.json to include 
```           
 "osx": {
    "pythonPath": "frameworkpython"
 }
```

with this modification I could easily use  Matplotlib. Immediately after updating to 1.9.1 I have now provide the full path to the `frameworkpython` file which tells me that the environment variables from the Virtual Env that I am using are no longer being honored in VS Code

data.title: Issues with VSCode Typescript Updates - version mismatch between the globally installed one
data.body:
when faced with this nagging complaint...

![index 25](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22841888/246bf81c-ef88-11e6-8dea-a15ae35bc2a5.jpg)

## There is neither clear directions to fix the problem nor does VSCode offer to perform a fix

The user in my case wants to be notified if there is a conflict and the current project setting are not saying "ignore I have a custom path (revision) for this project".
So "Don't Check Again" does not appear to be an option for me, besides, it keeps re-surfacing after VSCode updates.

![question-man](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22845335/feba9b6e-ef96-11e6-850e-f05f892f38da.png)



### "More Information" button points here
https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/languages/typescript#_using-newer-typescript-versions



![index 26](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22841952/5f49eb42-ef88-11e6-8a62-4eda45de1c13.jpg)

### "typescript.tsdk" is not working...

I  did specify "typescript.tsdk" but It does not get rid of the warning, nor do I know it is working and using my current project local copy for this project.
![question-man](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22845335/feba9b6e-ef96-11e6-850e-f05f892f38da.png)

## It's not obvious where the "workspace settings" are

The should say File > Preferences > "WORKSPACE SETTINGS" tab.
Or simply say open your current project .vcode/settings.json file 
![index 28](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22841984/7e4d8206-ef88-11e6-828c-99fd0c1479fb.jpg)



### Should the path point to lib or bin ?
so is it
`
    , "typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/lib"
`
or 
`
    , "typescript.tsdk": "./node_modules/typescript/bin"
`
![question-man](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22845335/feba9b6e-ef96-11e6-850e-f05f892f38da.png)

## Where does VSCode store it's copy of TypeScript and how to find out what version it is?

If "global" version of tsc is 2.14 where did VSCode language service 2.1.6 get installed?
From the VSCode complaints/warning above there is a typescript 2.1.6 somewhere???

![question-man](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22845335/feba9b6e-ef96-11e6-850e-f05f892f38da.png)

## Which version(s) of TypeScript are installed NPM Globally?
You can find the TypeScript installation location globally using  
```
npm list -g typescript
```
![index 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22842001/8d824eb4-ef88-11e6-878d-d23d74d344ff.jpg)



## Which version(s) of TypeScript are installed NPM locally?
```
npm list typescript
```
![index 29](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11699920/22842086/c987a1ca-ef88-11e6-8d50-6df4cc53ee76.jpg)

Please fix these annoyances.
 Thank you.

data.title: Add a "select all" button to the find UI
data.body:
Sublime Text has three buttons in its Find UI: Find, Find Prev, and Find All.

VSCode has the Prev and Next buttons (as arrow icons) but no button to find/select all. There is a keyboard shortcut to select all (Command+Enter on OS X), but a button in the UI would make the feature much more discoverable.

In my case, since the button was missing I instead tried using the command palette to search for a command to select all results. I found Select All Occurrences of Find Match (Shift+Command+L on OS X) but that behaved badlyit replaced the regular expression I was searching for with the currently-selected text, and so it didn't select the items I was searching for. I'd argue that that command should have preserved my original search term, but that's a separate issue.

- VSCode Version: 1.9
- OS Version: OS X El Capitan.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open the Find UI and type a search term.
2. Notice there is no button to select all instances.

data.title: Move to next line on comment (via key-command).
data.body:
Feature Request:

When using the comment key-command (default ctrl+/), I would like to have the caret move to the next line. 

This is a feature seen in the IDEA IDE (IntelliJ and family), and is very useful for quickly commenting and uncommenting lines of code without the mouse. 

This would work well as a setting.

data.title: Multi-cursor find not working with regex
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.9.1 (f9d0c687ff2ea7aabd85fb9a43129117c0ecf519, 2017-02-08T23:31:51.320Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.5.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-markdownlint|DavidAnson|0.6.2|
|beautify|HookyQR|0.7.3|
|alignment|annsk|0.3.0|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.1|
|path-intellisense|christian-kohler|1.2.0|
|prettier-vscode|esbenp|0.8.0|
|git-project-manager|felipecaputo|1.0.1|
|auto-close-tag|formulahendry|0.3.9|
|auto-rename-tag|formulahendry|0.0.11|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|2.5.3|
|java|redhat|0.0.10|
|vscode-react-native|vsmobile|0.2.5|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open a document with more than one line
2. Open find dialog (COMMAND+F)
3. Turn on regex find if it isn't already (COMMAND+OPTION+R)
4. Search for ^. You should now have any many find results as lines
5. Multi-cursor select (COMMAND+SHIFT+L)

I would expect as many cursors as I have lines. I only get one cursor though. 

Works as expected without the regex. If I just have 10 lines with the word start at the beginning of each line and I follow the above steps and search for 'start' I get 10 cursors.

I would also prefer COMMAND+SHIFT+L changes focus to the editor instead of the remaining on the find dialog. But that's more of an enhancement request.

data.title: Make Playground a generic component and expose it to extensions
data.body:
Users have a good time with our Welcome page and Playground in this release. Especially for new users, they get a chance to know how to use our editor to enhance their producibility, the interactive experience is awesome for education.

I'm thinking if it's possible that we can expose this feature to extensions, a good use case can be

1. Peng writes a markdown file with embedded code snippets of simple Ruby code in his Ruby extension.
2. Register the markdown file as a specific Playground scheme.
3. When users install the Ruby extension, they can open the playground page, directly edit those code snippets as now they are put in real editors.
4. They can run the snippet and see the results in output or preview page (We already have such an extension called Run Code to handle this), **without** setting up a new project/workspace for them.

IMHO, every Language Extension can use this to help educate beginners.

data.title: Test: tree/list navigation commands
data.body:
- [x] win @roblourens 
- [x] os x @mjbvz 
- [x] linux @isidorn 

Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/11517

We introduced new commands (see below) to make working with trees and lists more configurable for keyboard centric users. 

* verify for all adopters (see below) that the keybindings are working and you can also change them (e.g. take the example of a VIM user that wants to use <kbd>j</kbd>, <kbd>k</kbd>, <kbd>l</kbd>, <kbd>i</kbd> for navigation in the tree
* verify you are not getting into a state where keys suddenly do not work anymore even though the tree/list has focus (interesting corner cases: rename box in files explorer)

Here is a list of new commands that will work in every tree and list (unless specifically overridden, for example the files explorer on macOS does not open on <kbd>Enter</kbd>, but rather goes into rename mode. instead, <kbd>Cmd+Enter</kbd> will open from the explorer):

|Command|Keybinding|
|---|---|
|`list.focusUp`|`kbstyle(Up Arrow)` (additionally on macOS: `kbstyle(Ctrl+P)`)|
|`list.focusDown`|`kbstyle(Down Arrow)` (additionally on macOS: `kbstyle(Ctrl+N)`)|
|`list.focusFirst`|`kbstyle(Home)`|
|`list.focusLast`|`kbstyle(End)`|
|`list.focusPageDown`|`kbstyle(PageDown)`|
|`list.focusPageUp`|`kbstyle(PageUp)`|
|`list.collapse`|`kbstyle(Left Arrow)` (additionally on macOS: `kbstyle(Cmd+Up Arrow)`)|
|`list.expand`|`kbstyle(Right Arrow)`|
|`list.clear`|`kbstyle(Escape)`|
|`list.select`|`kbstyle(Enter)` (additionally on macOS: `kbstyle(Cmd+Enter)`)|
|`list.toggleExpand`|`kbstyle(Space)`|

**Adopters**:
* Files Explorer
* Opened Editors
* SCM Viewlet
* Problems
* Quick open (use tab to jump into tree)
* Search (pay attention that you still see search results opening while you navigate through results)
* Extensions List
* Extension Dependencies (e.g. try with "Azure Pack")
* Debug Hover (click into it to give focus)
* Debug Variables View
* Debug Watch Expressions
* Debug Call Stack
* Debug Breakpoints
* Debug Repl (click into to give focus)

data.title: Test: configurable explorer commands
data.body:
- [x] win @weinand 
- [x] os x @rebornix
- [x] linux @jrieken 

Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4557

The keybindings for actions within the files explorer and opened editors view are now mostly configurable and reimplemented as commands. 
* verify you can still trigger the commands via keybinding as before when the tree has focus
* verify you can change the command keybindings and you can still trigger them

**Commands that work in both files explorer and opened editors view**
* `explorer.openToSide`: opening to the side
* `explorer.copyPath`: copy path of file/folder
* `explorer.revealInOS`: reveal file in OS

**Commands that only work in the files explorer**
* `explorer.newFile`
* `explorer.newFolder`
* `filesExplorer.copy`: copy a file from the files explorer
* `filesExplorer.paste`: paste a file that was copied from the files explorer
* `filesExplorer.rename`: rename a file/folder in files explorer
* `filesExplorer.moveFileToTrash`: move a file/folder to trash from files explorer
* `filesExplorer.deleteFile`: bypass trash and delete a file/folder from files explorer
* `filesExplorer.findInFolder`: find inside a folder from the files explorer

In addition to these commands, the following contexts are introduced for keybindings:
* `filesExplorerFocus`: keyboard focus is inside the files explorer
* `openEditorsFocus`: keyboard focus is inside the opened editors view
* `explorerViewletFocus`: keyboard focus is in either of the two
